sen.j: 観応元年3月15日（1350年4月30日）、誕生。

sen.j: 康応2年/明徳元年（1390年）、「本願寺」を継承し第五世になるも、まもなく寺務を法嗣である第2子の巧如に委任し、越中国杉谷に草庵を結び居所とする。
sen.e: Although he was appointed as the fifth chief priest of "Hongan-ji Temple" in 1390, soon after he entrusted the practical running of the temple to his second son Gyonyo who was his hoshi (a successor to an abbacy) in order to build and live in a soan (a hermitage built with a simple structure with a thatched roof) in Sugitani of Ecchu Province.

sen.j: 明から朝廷に送られてきた難解な国書を読むのに、青蓮院は綽如を推挙し、上洛する。
sen.e: Shakunyo moved to Kyoto upon being recommended by Shoren-in Temple as a scholar who excelled at deciphering the difficult sovereign's messages sent from Ming to the Japanese imperial court.

sen.j: 綽如によって、その国書の内容が分かり、また返書の草稿も書く。
sen.e: Shakunyo translated the contents of the sovereign's messages, and also wrote the drafts of reply on behalf of the court.

sen.e: Emperor Gokomatsu praised his talent and achievements, and gave him the title of Shuen jonin (a circumferential holy priest).

sen.j: また後小松天皇より、宮中で『無量寿経』を講ずることを依頼される。
sen.e: Emperor Gokomatsu also requested him to give lectures on "Muryojukyo Sutra" at the imperial court.

sen.e: When Emperor Gokomatsu learned that Shakunyo had a dream of erecting a temple, he permitted him to make "kanjinjo" (a letter of temple solicitation) and gave him "ryoshi" (special paper for writing).

sen.e: Shakunyo returned to Ecchu Province and completed "kanjinjo" (now preserved as a National important cultural asset), and with it, he solicited donations in Kaga, Noto, Ecchu, Echigo, Shinano and Hida for erecting the temple.
